How could Zuma cease to be president?
* Death: unlikely, but not impossible. Odds are certainly 2 to 4 percent for the next year (see for the US: https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html; cf. http://flowingdata.com/projects/2015/life/).
* Vote of no confidence by parliament: party has majority (249 out of 400 seats), Zuma won previous votes of no confidence (party discipline in South Africa seems to be strict, according to expert judgment: http://constitutionallyspeaking.co.za/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/De-Vos-Party-2015.pdf; https://www.jstor.org/stable/723341?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents). But might be possible if he loses the backing of ANC (see below). Will see in August…
* Impeachment: Did not happen, so far. There is no discussion about it, so far. Would be disastrous for ANC… better would be to remove him.
* Disastrous re-election prospects for 2019: President is elected by parliament; so it comes down to ANC electoral prospects. Zuma cannot run for the presidential office since there is a term limit of two consecutive terms. ANC won the regional election by 54 percent of the vote share (this was after the first corruption charges were raised); so there is a downward momentum (additionally to a large number of ANC voters that did not vote at all) that could do harm to the hegemonic status of ANC in the South African party system (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_municipal_elections,_2016). This is underscored by polls for 2019 (http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/anc-faces-real-prospect-of-losing-2019-poll-8752385), approval ratings (http://www.enca.com/south-africa/polls-south-africans-disappointed-by-political-leadership), and the demonstrations. * And alternatives that emerge in ANC to Zuma: There is some dissatisfaction with Zuma. There is the pressure to present somebody other than Zuma (due to the presidential term limit). Generally, there are competent and even charismatic options, such as Pravin Gordhan or Gwede Mantashe, but they need a power base at the ANC that suffices to get the majority of the party behind themselves. What will happen if he ceases to be president?
* Acting president if he is unable to act as president (but not stepping down).
* Deputy president and others… 
* …until the National Assembly votes for a new president. Reference class: How do other heads of state perform which were in a similar situation? 
Usually, I think, they should be very likely to step down. But South Africa is not Europe or a well-established democracy in the Americas or Asia. Besides this, we have just witnessed the considerable persistence of South Korean president Park Geun-hye. There is. however. the important difference to other presidents that Zuma can be removed from office by the parliament's vote of no confidence, effectively by the ANC.  Forecasting:
* The removal becomes more likely the closer the 2019 elections come, the less favorable the electoral prospects for the ANC get and the more clearly an alternative to Zuma emerges…
* Prediction markets present odds for Zuma's ceasing to be president until the end of 2017 of 14 percent. I think, this is a little underrated and would take a bet up to 1:4, i.e. 20 percent.
* I think the probability after 2017 increases slightly non-linear: so I guess, the probability for ceasing to be president before the elections in 2019 (probably in May) and handing over to someone who can gain voting support with an advantage of incumbency is at least 50 percent, probably around 60 to 70 percent.
